conclusion: The force F is horizontal while the slope makes an angle θ = 37° with the horizontal.
Components of F are F∥ = F cos θ along the slope and F⊥ = F sin θ perpendicular to the slope.
Along the slope (up-slope taken as +): T – mg sin θ – fA = 0.
The friction is kinetic (impending upward motion) and acts down the plane: fA = μ NA.
Normal reaction on A: NA = mg cos θ.
T = mg sin θ + μ mg cos θ = mg (sin θ + μ cos θ).
Normal reaction on B: NB = mg cos θ + F sin θ.
Along the slope: F cos θ – T – mg sin θ – fB = 0 with fB = μ NB acting down the slope.
Insert (2) and (3) in (4): F cos θ – [mg(sin θ + μ cos θ)] – mg sin θ – μ[mg cos θ + F sin θ] = 0.
Collect the F–terms on the left and the weight terms on the right: F(cos θ – μ sin θ) = 2 mg sin θ + 2 μ mg cos θ.
Solve for F: F = 2 mg (sin θ + μ cos θ) / (cos θ – μ sin θ).
Numerator: sin θ + μ cos θ = 0.6 + 0.5 × 0.8 = 1.0. Denominator: cos θ – μ sin θ = 0.8 – 0.5 × 0.6 = 0.5.
The magnitude of the horizontal force that puts the two sliders just on the verge of moving up the incline is F = 4 mg (≈ 39.2 m newtons if g ≈ 9.8 m s⁻²).
